Source: https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui

Expand description

![Image 1: Release header](https://github.com/ratatui/ratatui/blob/b23480adfa9430697071c906c7ba4d4f9bd37a73/assets/release-header.png?raw=true)

[Ratatui](https://ratatui.rs/) is a crate for cooking up terminal user interfaces in Rust. It is a lightweight library that provides a set of [widgets](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/index.html "mod ratatui::widgets") and utilities to build complex Rust TUIs. Ratatui was forked from the [tui-rs](https://crates.io/crates/tui) crate in 2023 in order to continue its development.

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#quickstart)Quickstart

Add `ratatui` and `crossterm` as dependencies to your cargo.toml:

`cargo add ratatui crossterm`

Then you can create a simple “Hello World” application:

```
use crossterm::event;

fn main() -> std::io::Result<()> {
    ratatui::run(|mut terminal| {
        loop {
            terminal.draw(|frame| frame.render_widget("Hello World!", frame.area()))?;
            if event::read()?.is_key_press() {
                break Ok(());
            }
        }
    })
}
```

The full code for this example which contains a little more detail is in the [Examples](https://github.com/ratatui/ratatui/tree/main/ratatui/examples/README.md) directory. For more guidance on different ways to structure your application see the [Application Patterns](https://ratatui.rs/concepts/application-patterns/) and [Hello Ratatui tutorial](https://ratatui.rs/tutorials/hello-ratatui/) sections in the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) and the various [Examples](https://github.com/ratatui/ratatui/tree/main/ratatui/examples/README.md). There are also several starter [Templates](https://ratatui.rs/templates/) available to help you get started quickly with common patterns.

[§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#crate-organization)Crate Organization
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Starting with Ratatui 0.30.0, the project was reorganized into a modular workspace to improve compilation times, API stability, and dependency management. Most applications should continue using this main `ratatui` crate, which re-exports everything for convenience:

*   **[`ratatui`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/index.html "mod ratatui")**: Main crate with complete functionality (recommended for apps)
*   **[`ratatui-core`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-core)**: Core traits and types for widget libraries
*   **[`ratatui-widgets`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-widgets)**: Built-in widget implementations
*   **Backend crates**: [`ratatui-crossterm`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-crossterm), [`ratatui-termion`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-termion), [`ratatui-termwiz`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-termwiz)
*   **[`ratatui-macros`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-macros)**: Macros for simplifying the boilerplate

**For application developers**: No changes needed - continue using `ratatui` as before.

**For widget library authors**: Consider depending on [`ratatui-core`](https://crates.io/crates/ratatui-core) instead of the full `ratatui` crate for better API stability and reduced dependencies.

See [ARCHITECTURE.md](https://github.com/ratatui/ratatui/blob/main/ARCHITECTURE.md) for detailed information about the crate organization and design decisions.

[§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#writing-applications)Writing Applications
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ratatui is based on the principle of immediate rendering with intermediate buffers. This means that for each frame, your app must render all [`widgets`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/index.html "mod ratatui::widgets") that are supposed to be part of the UI. This is in contrast to the retained mode style of rendering where widgets are updated and then automatically redrawn on the next frame. See the [Rendering](https://ratatui.rs/concepts/rendering/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for more info.

Ratatui uses [Crossterm](https://crates.io/crates/crossterm) by default as it works on most platforms. See the [Installation](https://ratatui.rs/installation/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for more details on how to use other backends ([Termion](https://crates.io/crates/termion) / [Termwiz](https://crates.io/crates/termwiz)).

Every application built with `ratatui` needs to implement the following steps:

*   Initialize the terminal (see the [`init` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/init/index.html "mod ratatui::init") for convenient initialization functions)
*   A main loop that: 
    *   Draws the UI
    *   Handles input events

*   Restore the terminal state

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#initialize-and-restore-the-terminal)Initialize and restore the terminal

The simplest way to initialize and run a terminal application is to use the [`run()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.run.html "fn ratatui::run") function, which handles terminal initialization, restoration, and panic hooks automatically:

```
fn main() -> std::io::Result<()> {
    ratatui::run(|mut terminal| {
        loop {
            terminal.draw(render)?;
            if should_quit()? {
                break Ok(());
            }
        }
    })
}

fn render(frame: &mut ratatui::Frame) {
    // ...
}

fn should_quit() -> std::io::Result<bool> {
    // ...
}
```

For more control over initialization and restoration, you can use [`init()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.init.html "fn ratatui::init") and [`restore()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.restore.html "fn ratatui::restore"):

```
fn main() -> std::io::Result<()> {
    let mut terminal = ratatui::init();
    let result = run_app(&mut terminal);
    ratatui::restore();
    result
}

fn run_app(terminal: &mut ratatui::DefaultTerminal) -> std::io::Result<()> {
    loop {
        terminal.draw(render)?;
        if should_quit()? {
            break Ok(());
        }
    }
}
```

Note that when using [`init()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.init.html "fn ratatui::init") and [`restore()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.restore.html "fn ratatui::restore"), it’s important to use a separate function for the main loop to ensure that [`restore()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.restore.html "fn ratatui::restore") is always called, even if the `?` operator causes early return from an error.

For more detailed information about initialization options and when to use each function, see the [`init` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/init/index.html "mod ratatui::init") documentation.

#### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#manual-terminal-and-backend-construction)Manual Terminal and Backend Construction

Before the convenience functions were introduced in version 0.28.1 ([`init()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.init.html "fn ratatui::init")/[`restore()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.restore.html "fn ratatui::restore")) and 0.30.0 ([`run()`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.run.html "fn ratatui::run")), applications constructed [`Terminal`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html "struct ratatui::Terminal") and [`Backend`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/trait.Backend.html "trait ratatui::backend::Backend") instances manually. This approach is still supported for applications that need fine-grained control over initialization. See the [`Terminal`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html "struct ratatui::Terminal") and [`backend`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/trait.Backend.html "trait ratatui::backend::Backend") module documentation for details.

See the [`backend` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/index.html "mod ratatui::backend") and the [Backends](https://ratatui.rs/concepts/backends/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for more info on the alternate screen and raw mode. Learn more about different backend options in the [Backend Comparison](https://ratatui.rs/concepts/backends/comparison/) guide.

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#drawing-the-ui)Drawing the UI

Drawing the UI is done by calling the [`Terminal::draw`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html#method.draw "method ratatui::Terminal::draw") method on the terminal instance. This method takes a closure that is called with a [`Frame`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Frame.html "struct ratatui::Frame") instance. The [`Frame`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Frame.html "struct ratatui::Frame") provides the size of the area to draw to and allows the app to render any [`Widget`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/trait.Widget.html "trait ratatui::prelude::Widget") using the provided [`render_widget`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Frame.html#method.render_widget "method ratatui::Frame::render_widget") method. After this closure returns, a diff is performed and only the changes are drawn to the terminal. See the [Widgets](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/widgets/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) and the [Widget Recipes](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/widgets/) for more info on creating effective UIs.

The closure passed to the [`Terminal::draw`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html#method.draw "method ratatui::Terminal::draw") method should handle the rendering of a full frame. For guidance on setting up the terminal before drawing, see the [`init` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/init/index.html "mod ratatui::init") documentation.

```
use ratatui::Frame;
use ratatui::widgets::Paragraph;

fn run(terminal: &mut ratatui::DefaultTerminal) -> std::io::Result<()> {
    loop {
        terminal.draw(|frame| render(frame))?;
        if handle_events()? {
            break Ok(());
        }
    }
}

fn render(frame: &mut Frame) {
    let text = Paragraph::new("Hello World!");
    frame.render_widget(text, frame.area());
}
```

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#handling-events)Handling events

Ratatui does not include any input handling. Instead event handling can be implemented by calling backend library methods directly. See the [Handling Events](https://ratatui.rs/concepts/event-handling/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for conceptual information. For example, if you are using [Crossterm](https://crates.io/crates/crossterm), you can use the [`crossterm::event`](https://docs.rs/crossterm/latest/crossterm/event/index.html) module to handle events.

```
use crossterm::event::{self, Event, KeyCode, KeyEvent, KeyEventKind};

fn handle_events() -> std::io::Result<bool> {
    match event::read()? {
        Event::Key(key) if key.kind == KeyEventKind::Press => match key.code {
            KeyCode::Char('q') => return Ok(true),
            // handle other key events
            _ => {}
        },
        // handle other events
        _ => {}
    }
    Ok(false)
}
```

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#layout-1)Layout

The library comes with a basic yet useful layout management object called [`Layout`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Layout.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Layout") which allows you to split the available space into multiple areas and then render widgets in each area. This lets you describe a responsive terminal UI by nesting layouts. See the [Layout](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/layout/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for more info, and check out the [Layout Recipes](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/layout/) for practical examples.

```
use ratatui::Frame;
use ratatui::layout::{Constraint, Layout};
use ratatui::widgets::Block;

fn draw(frame: &mut Frame) {
    use Constraint::{Fill, Length, Min};

    let vertical = Layout::vertical([Length(1), Min(0), Length(1)]);
    let [title_area, main_area, status_area] = vertical.areas(frame.area());
    let horizontal = Layout::horizontal([Fill(1); 2]);
    let [left_area, right_area] = horizontal.areas(main_area);

    frame.render_widget(Block::bordered().title("Title Bar"), title_area);
    frame.render_widget(Block::bordered().title("Status Bar"), status_area);
    frame.render_widget(Block::bordered().title("Left"), left_area);
    frame.render_widget(Block::bordered().title("Right"), right_area);
}
```

Running this example produces the following output:

```
Title Bar───────────────────────────────────
┌Left────────────────┐┌Right───────────────┐
│                    ││                    │
└────────────────────┘└────────────────────┘
Status Bar──────────────────────────────────
```

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#text-and-styling)Text and styling

The [`Text`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Text.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Text"), [`Line`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Line.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Line") and [`Span`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Span.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Span") types are the building blocks of the library and are used in many places. [`Text`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Text.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Text") is a list of [`Line`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Line.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Line")s and a [`Line`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Line.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Line") is a list of [`Span`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Span.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Span")s. A [`Span`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Span.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Span") is a string with a specific style.

The [`style` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/style/index.html "mod ratatui::style") provides types that represent the various styling options. The most important one is [`Style`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Style.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Style") which represents the foreground and background colors and the text attributes of a [`Span`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/struct.Span.html "struct ratatui::prelude::Span"). The [`style` module](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/style/index.html "mod ratatui::style") also provides a [`Stylize`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/trait.Stylize.html "trait ratatui::prelude::Stylize") trait that allows short-hand syntax to apply a style to widgets and text. See the [Styling Text](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/render/style-text/) section of the [Ratatui Website](https://ratatui.rs/) for more info, and explore the [Styling Recipes](https://ratatui.rs/recipes/render/) for creative examples.

```
use ratatui::Frame;
use ratatui::layout::{Constraint, Layout};
use ratatui::style::{Color, Modifier, Style, Stylize};
use ratatui::text::{Line, Span};
use ratatui::widgets::{Block, Paragraph};

fn draw(frame: &mut Frame) {
    let areas = Layout::vertical([Constraint::Length(1); 4]).split(frame.area());

    let line = Line::from(vec![
        Span::raw("Hello "),
        Span::styled(
            "World",
            Style::new()
                .fg(Color::Green)
                .bg(Color::White)
                .add_modifier(Modifier::BOLD),
        ),
        "!".red().on_light_yellow().italic(),
    ]);
    frame.render_widget(line, areas[0]);

    // using the short-hand syntax and implicit conversions
    let paragraph = Paragraph::new("Hello World!".red().on_white().bold());
    frame.render_widget(paragraph, areas[1]);

    // style the whole widget instead of just the text
    let paragraph = Paragraph::new("Hello World!").style(Style::new().red().on_white());
    frame.render_widget(paragraph, areas[2]);

    // use the simpler short-hand syntax
    let paragraph = Paragraph::new("Hello World!").blue().on_yellow();
    frame.render_widget(paragraph, areas[3]);
}
```

### [§](http://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui#features)Features

The crate provides a set of optional features that can be enabled in your `Cargo.toml` file.

*   **`default`** — By default, we enable the crossterm backend as this is a reasonable choice for most applications as it is supported on Linux/Mac/Windows systems. We also enable the `underline-color` feature which allows you to set the underline color of text, the `macros` feature which provides some useful macros and `layout-cache` which speeds up layout cache calculations in `std`-enabled environments.

Generally an application will only use one backend, so you should only enable one of the following features:

*   **`crossterm`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables the [`CrosstermBackend`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/struct.CrosstermBackend.html "struct ratatui::backend::CrosstermBackend") backend and adds a dependency on [`crossterm`](https://docs.rs/crossterm/0.29.0/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/crossterm/index.html "mod crossterm").
*   **`crossterm_0_28`** — selects the crossterm 0.28.x backend implementation
*   **`crossterm_0_29`** — selects the crossterm 0.29.x backend implementation (default)
*   **`termion`** — enables the [`TermionBackend`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/struct.TermionBackend.html "struct ratatui::backend::TermionBackend") backend and adds a dependency on [`termion`](https://docs.rs/termion/4.0.6/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/termion/index.html "mod termion").
*   **`termwiz`** — enables the [`TermwizBackend`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/backend/struct.TermwizBackend.html "struct ratatui::backend::TermwizBackend") backend and adds a dependency on [`termwiz`](https://docs.rs/termwiz/0.23.3/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/termwiz/index.html "mod termwiz").
*   **`std`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables std

The following optional features are available for all backends:

*   **`serde`** — enables serialization and deserialization of style and color types using the [`serde`](https://docs.rs/serde/1.0.228/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/serde/index.html "mod serde") crate. This is useful if you want to save themes to a file.
*   **`layout-cache`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables layout cache
*   **`palette`** — enables conversions from colors in the [`palette`](https://docs.rs/palette/0.7.6/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/palette/index.html "mod palette") crate to [`Color`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/prelude/enum.Color.html "enum ratatui::prelude::Color").
*   **`portable-atomic`** — enables portable-atomic integration for targets that don’t support atomic types.
*   **`scrolling-regions`** — Use terminal scrolling regions to make some operations less prone to flickering. (i.e. Terminal::insert_before).
*   **`macros`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables the [`macros`](https://docs.rs/ratatui-macros/0.7.0/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/ratatui_macros/index.html "mod ratatui_macros") module which provides some useful macros for creating spans, lines, text, and layouts
*   **`all-widgets`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables all widgets.

Widgets that add dependencies are gated behind feature flags to prevent unused transitive dependencies. The available features are:

*   **`widget-calendar`**_(enabled by default)_ — enables the [`calendar`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/calendar/index.html "mod ratatui::widgets::calendar") widget module.

The following optional features are only available for some backends:

*   **`underline-color`**_(enabled by default)_ — Enables the backend code that sets the underline color. Underline color is only supported by the Crossterm and Termwiz backends, and is not supported on Windows 7.

The following features are unstable and may change in the future:

*   **`unstable`** — Enable all unstable features.

*   **`unstable-rendered-line-info`** — Enables the [`Paragraph::line_count`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/struct.Paragraph.html#method.line_count "method ratatui::widgets::Paragraph::line_count")[`Paragraph::line_width`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/struct.Paragraph.html#method.line_width "method ratatui::widgets::Paragraph::line_width") methods which are experimental and may change in the future. See [Issue 293](https://github.com/ratatui/ratatui/issues/293) for more details.

*   **`unstable-widget-ref`** — enables the [`WidgetRef`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/trait.WidgetRef.html "trait ratatui::widgets::WidgetRef") and [`StatefulWidgetRef`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/trait.StatefulWidgetRef.html "trait ratatui::widgets::StatefulWidgetRef") traits which are experimental and may change in the future.

*   **`unstable-backend-writer`** — Enables getting access to backends’ writers.

`pub use palette;``palette``pub use ratatui_crossterm::crossterm;``crossterm``pub use ratatui_macros as macros;``macros``pub use ratatui_termion::termion;`Non-Windows and `termion``pub use returns a combination of the [`Borders`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/widgets/struct.Borders.html "struct ratatui::widgets::Borders") object from TOP, BOTTOM, LEFT and RIGHT.[Completed Frame](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.CompletedFrame.html "struct ratatui::CompletedFrame")`CompletedFrame` represents the state of the terminal after all changes performed in the last [`Terminal::draw`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html#method.draw "method ratatui::Terminal::draw") call have been applied. Therefore, it is only valid until the next call to [`Terminal::draw`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html#method.draw "method ratatui::Terminal::draw").[Frame](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Frame.html "struct ratatui::Frame")A consistent view into the terminal state for rendering a single frame.[Terminal](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html "struct ratatui::Terminal")An interface to interact and draw [`Frame`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Frame.html "struct ratatui::Frame")s on the user’s terminal.[Terminal Options](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.TerminalOptions.html "struct ratatui::TerminalOptions")Options to pass to [`Terminal::with_options`](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/struct.Terminal.html#method.with_options "associated function ratatui::Terminal::with_options")[Viewport](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/enum.Viewport.html "enum ratatui::Viewport")Represents the viewport of the terminal. The viewport is the area of the terminal that is currently visible to the user. It can be either fullscreen, inline or fixed.[init](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.init.html "fn ratatui::init")`crossterm`Initialize a terminal with reasonable defaults for most applications.[init_ with_ options](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.init_with_options.html "fn ratatui::init_with_options")`crossterm`Initialize a terminal with the given options and reasonable defaults.[restore](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.restore.html "fn ratatui::restore")`crossterm`Restores the terminal to its original state.[run](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.run.html "fn ratatui::run")`crossterm`Run a closure with a terminal initialized with reasonable defaults for most applications.[try_ init](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.try_init.html "fn ratatui::try_init")`crossterm`Try to initialize a terminal using reasonable defaults for most applications.[try_ init_ with_ options](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.try_init_with_options.html "fn ratatui::try_init_with_options")`crossterm`Try to initialize a terminal with the given options and reasonable defaults.[try_ restore](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/fn.try_restore.html "fn ratatui::try_restore")`crossterm`Restore the terminal to its original state.[Default Terminal](https://docs.rs/ratatui/latest/ratatui/type.DefaultTerminal.html "type ratatui::DefaultTerminal")`crossterm`A type alias for the default terminal type.
